But in thy heart his sting.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O do not say so:
My heart is honest still, unless thou spoildst it
When it receiv'd thee in. 'T had but three corners.
And thou hadst two, at least. Would thou couldst see
How little room I've left my self there in it.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Yes; for 'tis crouded up with many guests;
So many guests, that they excluded me:
And now I freeze without; but never more,
Never will enter: 'twas a Palace once,
But now tis turn'd a Dungeon.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: Will you leave me?
I will not call you fickle nor unconstant;
But sure you are too blame: you will not find
A woman that will love you half so well.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: I do not mean to try.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes, prithee do.
But when y'have talk'd, and lov'd and vow'd, and sworn
A little while, take heed of using her
As you do me. No, may your love to her
Be such as mine to you; it can't be better,
What e'er you think; I'm sure it cannot, Truman.
May she be worthier of your bed then I,
And bring forth many little selves to you:
And when the happie course of divers yeers
Makes you seem old to all besides your wife,
May you in the fair glass of your blest issue,
See your own youth again. But I would have 'um
True in their loves, and kill no innocent maids.
For me it is no matter: when I'm dead,
My busie soul shall slutter still about you;
'Twill not be else in heaven: it shall watch
Over your sleeps, and drive away all dreams
That flie not with a soft and downy wing.
If any dangers threaten, it shall becken,
And call your spirit away till they be past;
And be more diligent then your Guardian-Angel.
Onely sometimes, when your best leasure serves,
(For I'd not trouble you more dead then living)
Bestow • ne thought on Lucia, and then sigh,
And (if you will) drop down a tear or two.
But that's a task Ill not enjoyn you to:
And if you do't, spend not too many on me;
One will suffice: then onely say, That maid
Deserv'd more of me. And again t'your business.
For my wrongd vertue and forsaken truth,
I ask no more. So, dear False-man, farewel.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: It makes my frighted soul start back and tremble.
'Tis but an aery word. D'ye hear me, Lucia?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: (within) Who calls?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Farewel, Lucia, farewel; that's all: farewel
Repent, and meet me in heav'n—
Why did rash Nature quarrel with her self,
In making one so excellently bad?

She is more fair then May
• s new painted blossoms,
But falser then the smiles of faithless April:
And this I know, and yet me thinks I love her.
O she has kill'd my Reason: I have lost
That and my self for ever. Exit.
Every thing now has left me; tears themselves,
The riches of my very grief, forsake me:
Sorrow, me thinks, shews nakedly without ' • m.
My sighs are spent too; and my wearied lungs
Deny me fresh supplies: and I appear

Like some dull melancholy
• pril-even,
When after many a showre the heav'ns still lowre,
As if they threatned more; and the s • ed Sun
Leaves nothing but a doubtful blush behinde him.
And I could wish my eternal night were coming,
Did I but know who 'tis that makes me wish it:
Else, when my soul is ready for her slight,
And knows not who it is she must forgive,
A thousand light suspicions will call
Her charity several ways; and I may chance
To doubt thee, T • uman. But thou art abus'd:
I know not why; but sure thou couldst not do it.
I fear thee, cousin When we were both girls,
Thou wouldst accuse me falsely to my Mistress,
And laugh to see my tears. I fear thee, cousin;
But I'll not judge too rashly: for I would not
Have any innocent wrong'd as I have been.
But I • m resolv'd to try her. She's now seeking
(Hoping that all my fortunes now are hers)
For a new maid t'attend her. That maid I'll be.
Cloathes I have got already; and my face
Grief has disguis'd: that and my voice some art
Will quickly alter. I have left a Note
Upon my chamber-window, which will keep 'um
From all suspicion of my staying here.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Hei! the Sisters are ravisht, and we have holy kisses enough. I shall be as great among 'um as—Who's there? What, your Spouse, Pury?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: She looks like Niobe on the mountains top.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: That Niobe, Dogrel, you have us'd worse then Phoebus did. Not a dog looks melancholy, but he's compar'd to Niobe. He beat a villanous Tapster t'other day, to make him look like Niobe.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Why 'faith that 's pretty odde, like one o' mine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O, Sir, had you the vertuous impudence to slander a poor maid thus?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Poor enough now indeed. I will not marry thee: thy portion was a condition of the Contract. I'll sooner marry a woman that sells Orenges with a face like Belinsgate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I scorn thee—I contracted to thee?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Wert not? Answer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Bear witness, Gentlemen; these words are Ca • duus benedictus to me.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And what will you do now, fair Gammer Lucia, you that contemn'd the Colonel? Will you knit for your living?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Or else weed gardens for six pence a day and bread.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is unheard-of rudeness.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Nay let me ha' mine too; I ha' got a pat one for her. Or else turn Apple-woman, live in a stall, and sell pippins for eight a peny.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Or hither in triumph 'twixt two panniers ride,
And sell the bouls of wheat and butter in Cheapside.
The last is a little too long: but I imitate Spencer.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: What think ye, Gentlemen? she'll make a pretty Landress.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: A Landress? hang her, she looks like a foul handkercher.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray let me go; I ha' business requires me.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: What? you're to meet some Gentlemen? How is't? twelve pence a time, I warrant, in these cloathes.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Where do you set up? Nay, we are true strikers. What, is't in Covent-garden?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Or do you renew the decay'd credit of Turnbal-street?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Or honour the Mill-bank at Westminster.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Or flee to Wapping, and engross the Sailors.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Or Moor-fields, and sell cakes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Are all barbarous here?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Nay tell's; we shall be customers.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Enough, enough; give her a clap o'the breech, and let her go.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Well, fare thee well, girl; we shall finde you at the Play house i' the six-peny-room sometimes.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: And d'ye hear, Lucia, Keep your self wholesome: your tub's a terrible thing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Unworthy villains— But I'm born to wrongs,
And must endure 'um. Exit.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: A pretty Scene i'faith. Now for the Captain; he'll entertain us like forraign Princes: we'll drink this half-yeer with him before we eat or sleep.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I'll drink like Gog-Magog himself, or the Spanish Tinker on a holy-day.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: There will I whet my Lyrick Muse
With Falern wine as I do use.
Captain Blade cannot refuse
To entertain us; he cannot chuse,
When we bring him such good news,
As that his neece is gone to the stews.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Leave your verses, Dogrel. I hate your verses, Dogrel, till I be drunk. 'Tis a glorious Captain.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: As free as Free-town in Germany▪ Here comes Ieronymo.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: The story says my neece is run away. The story is not bad. Now will I get the widow, turn off my old rascally companions, and live like an Emperour.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: He says he will live like an Emperour; ha, ha, ha, brave Captain.

sp.speaker: Pun
sp.p: Invincible Captain Priam.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Hei brave Captain!

sp.speaker: Bla
sp.p: What do you mean, Gentlemen? Are ye broke loose from Bedlam? Ha' you no other place to play your tricks in, but at my door? If you come here as Mummers, much may be done; haply you may have twelve-pence: or else depart; depart, if you be wise.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Why how now, Captain!

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: If you be not gone immediately, I'll ha' my men switch you further off—Here are saucy knaves indeed with all my heart—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: By this light the Captain's drunk without us.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Prethee, Captain, thou art as humorous as a bell-rope. Dost thou know me, man? I'm M. Puny.

sp.speaker: Blade.
sp.p:
Y' are a fool, an addle egge: there's nothing else but cobwebs i' your
head: The height of all thy knowledge is to find out the quarter day against thy rents come in, and thou couldst not finde out that, if 'twere not marke'd i'the Almanack with red letters. Yet you forsooth, because you see some Gentlemen and Poets of late, a little extravagant sometimes in their similitudes; because they make a pretty kinde of sound to those that mark 'um not; make that your way of wit, and never speak without comparisons. But never were comparisons so odious as thine are. And these two Rabbit-suckers, for a quart of wine extol thee, and cry good when thou speakest so.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: The Captains raging mad like a Baker when his oven is over heated.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: And that was one of um—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Come leave your humors, hang you, confound you, pox take you, Captain, we come to drink here.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Mine's no blind Ale-house, where you may roar and swagger with half a pipe of Tobacco in your mouth.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Do you know me, Captain?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I would I never had. Thou art one that sayest thou hast seen the wars, but thou liest basely; for if thou ever wast in a battle, i'm sure thou winkest there. Thou art one that liv'st like a Raven by providence and rapine: one that if thou shouldst chance to go to bed sober, thou wouldst put it down in thy Almanack for an unlucky day; sleep is not death's image with thee, unless thou beest dead-drunk.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: He dares not abuse me thus.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Is't even so, Captain? Has your money exalted you?

sp.speaker: Bla
sp.p: No, it has humbled me, and made me know my self and you, whom I shall study to forget hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Come, Captain, shall you and I drink hand to hand?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Oh, you're his Lansprizado, Sirrah, Trundle.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Let not thy wrath swell like the Adrian Sea.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Thou that troublest thy self to be a fool; I will so beat thee, Trundle, that thou shalt hobble like one of thy own Rhyms. Therefore, if ever thou shewest that Poetical face of thine within my doors again, Ile use thee worse then thou didst me, when thou mad'st an Ode in commendation of me.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Then break thine oaten reed—

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Fare ye well Gentlemen. I shall see thee Cutter a brave Tapster shortly; it must be so i'faith, Cutter; thou must like Bardolph i'the play, the spiggot weild. Dogrel shall make and sell smal Pamphlets i'the playhouse, or else Tobacco, or else snuffe Candles. As for Puny, his means will serve him to be cheated of these five or six yeers.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: 'Tis very well the times are so alter'd.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Ye cannot want a living Gentlemen, as long as there are Whores, Bowling-allies, or Ordinaries; especially such able men as you are. There will be wars too shortly; never quake, Cutter; here's Dogrel, when his want has spun him out a little thinner, will serve you for a pike.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: 'Tis very well: pray God your mirth last, Captain.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: When you're grown old, and your fingers then only nimble with the palsie, I'll provide an Hospital for you—Sedes ubi fata quietas — Fare ye well, Gallants; and pray be merry: Fare ye well heartily.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Poverty, the pox, an ill wife, and the Devil go with thee, Captain.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I vexed him, when I put that jest upon him, like a Baker when his oven's overheated.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: If I don't compose a Satyre shall make him hang himself, may I never write verse more.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I would beat him like a Buck, but I shall be bound to the peace for't, and be affronted afterward by every one.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: No, no, no—let me see—Besides my Satyre I have another way—let me see—His brother traffickt at Guiny.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Yes, but the Merchants there report him dead.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: The more knaves they: he lives, and I am he.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: How? How, Dogrel, thou the Merchant man?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: By this light, I either am, or will be.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: How, Dogrel! Though thou be as thin and penetrable as a spirit, yet thou canst not assume dead bodies.

sp.speaker: Pun
sp.p: Prithee, Dog • el, hold thy peace; thou talkest like a hogs f • ce.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: De • ide not Puny: if I be not more like then any of your similitudes, I'll be hang • d for't.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Thy face, indeed, will do exceed • ng well to represent one risen from the grave

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: By long conversation with the Captain, I know all the passages between him and his brother; know what his humour, what his state and fortunes were, better then himself did when he lived.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I, but thou 'lt ne'er act him. Why, man, he was a thing more st • ange then any monster in Africk where he travell'd.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: What was he, prithee?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I knew him well enough; he had lost his memory, and therefore either writ down every thing, and took his business with him in a scroll, or else trusted it to his man Iohn, whom he carried with him.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: O I, that Iohn and he went perpetually together, like the blinde man and his dog.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Or a Tinker and his t • ull. But d'ye hear, gallants, let me do apple-Iohn: never was such a Iohn as I'll be, not Iohn a Gaunt himself, nor Iohn a Nook.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: But Dogrel, how wilt thou be made like that Cinque- • ater?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Why we Poets can do any thing. First you may remember (unless you be like him) 'tis seven yeers since he went from hence; and time, you know, will alter men. I made an Ode upon that subject once: Time, that dost eat, and makst no Lent—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Pox take your Ode; go on i' your business, Dogrel.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Then I and my man Iohn (as simply as he stands here) will swarthy over our faces as if the Countrey had made us so: for if you remember my verses, In Africk they are black as coals—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The devil's i' thy verses. Prithee on.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Besides, we'll be attir'd in some strange habit of those Countries: I know not how; but you shall see't in Speed, Maps.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p:
Why now I like thee, my little Ovid; go about thy Metamorphosis. I'm for Tabyth •
; she's taken, Dogrel,
• elted like virgins wax. I ll to her presently, and tell her that the vision appeared to me last, and warn'd me to carry her to S. 〈◊〉 ; there will I have a Priest.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: A Priest, Cutter?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: A Minister, I mean; a holy, godly, zealous Minister: and she—You conceive me, Dogrel—

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Well, let's be going then. Puny, take heed o' your wit when you act Iohn: I shall beat my servant Iohn, if he be witty.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: That's the devil; I shall hardly abstain.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And Dogrel, you must make no verses, Dogrel: let that be the first thing your memory fails you in.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Well, I'll follow you in a pissing-while.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Do so, good Iohn. Exit Dog. Cut.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Now will I turn Iohn, as round as a Wedding-ring: and if that plot be cut of • by the nose—Ha? Here comes sententious Bias that walks gravely. I'll observe my young Laconian.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: She's gone for ever. Peace be with thee, Lucia.
Where ever thou art.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.l: Now he begins his Epithala • ium.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: If she be guilty,
Forgive her, heav'n; she'll repent, I'm sure:
For she is soft, and melting as the dew,
And howsoe'er beauty and youth misled her,
She cannot be, I know, a stubborn sinner.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.l: Did ever Basket-maker talk thus?
to himself too, l • ke a Conjurer in a garden?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Ha! This is he, that wicked man,
That devil which betray'd her.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.l: O, are you thereabouts? Offers to go out.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Nay stay,
For wert thou arm'd with thunder and my anger,
Yet I would bring thee back. Tell me what charms,
(For I will rip thy heart up but I'll know it)
What witch-craft didst thou use t'entice her thus?
Never deny't. For hadst thou been more handsome
Then other mens, or thine own flattery
Could ever make thee: hast thou been as beautiful,
And couldst have spoke as well as she her self,
All this were nothing; she would look upon thee,
But lust no more then thine own Angel does.
No, thou didst use some cursed art to tempt her,
Some Philter—

sp.speaker: Pun
sp.l: Not I by all—what d'ye mean pray, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Why then you ravisht her, by Heav'n you ravisht her:
Alas, she's weak and tender, very tender,
And was not able to resist that strength
Which youth and furious lust did arm thee with.
'Twas basely done, above expression basely,
And I would presently revenge it fully,
But that my sword would take from the laws justice,
And from thy shame.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.l: I ravish her? By this light I scorn't.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: You did enjoy her body? Did you not?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.l: I did so.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: You did? I prithee do not say you did so;
This is to brag of the vile act th'ast done:
But I shall spoil your pride and shameful glory
Which your base sin affords you.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.l: You bid me tell you the truth, what would you ha'me do?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Do? I would have thee fix thy adulterous eye
Upon the ground, which thy cursed feet dishonour;
And blush more red then is the sin th'ast acted.
What would I have thee do? I'd have thee weep,
Shed as true tears as she does for thy fault,
And sigh away thy body into air.
What would I have thee do? I • d have thee kill thy self.
And sacrifice thy life to her wrong'd Soul.
Canst thou refuse to do all this for her,
For whom th'ast damn'd thy self?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.l: We were contracted first e'er I enjoyed her.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Didst thou enjoy her then? How durst thou do it?
Why she was mine, I tell thee she was mine;
All the Seas wealth should not have bought her from me,
While she remain'd as spotless as my love:
And so she did remain till thy sin stain'd her.
I tell thee to that hour she was more innocent
Then thou, false man, wert in thy mothers womb.
Didst thou enjoy her? Either fetch back that word,
Say, nay I'll have thee swear thou didst not touch her,
Or by those joyes which thou hast rob'd me of,
I'll kill thee strait.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: 'Siid I did not touch her. What would you ha' me say? would I were Iohn the Merchants man now.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: O Heav'ns! O most unheard of villany!
Th hast done a crime so great, that there is hardly
Mercy enough in Heav'n to pardon thee.
Tell me, (for now I'll argue mildly with thee)
Why should you seek t' undo a harmless maid?
To rob her of her friend • , her life perhaps,
I'm sure her fame, which is much dearer to her.
'Twas an inhuman act; an act so barbarous,
That Nations unciviliz'd would abhor it:
I dare say boldly she nev'r injured you;
For she was gentle as the breath of Zephyrus:
And if she e'er did but begin a thought
Of wronging any man, she would have wept
Before she thought it out.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I had rather be a pickl'd▪ Oister, then i'this case I am in now.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Is Lucia abus'd? and I stand here
T expostulate with words her injuries?
Draw, for I'll talk no more with thee.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: D'ye hear, Sir—by Heaven I lay with her, but we were contracted first—will you be pleas'd to hear me?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No, be gone.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Most willingly. Fare ye well heartily, Sir; I wish you a good night-cap.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: The want of sleep and diet has distempered me,
If I stay thus I shall be quite distracted;
Me thinks a kinde of strangeness seizes me:
And yet if I go home I shall be forc'd
To marry with Aurelia. Is it possible
There should be women good, if Lucia be not?
They are not sure: She lookt as well as any,
And spoke as well too.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: I tell you, Captain, he's a stubborn boy, a self-will'd hair-brain'd boy: he has his know-nots, and his wo'nots, and his may be's, when I speak. I have told him of his manner a hundred ti • es; nay I may say a thousand.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Pray take • y counsel for this once: though I be a souldier, yet I love not to do all things by force. Speak fairly to him.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: Speak fairly to my son? I'll see him buried, I'll see his eyes out first.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I mean, desire him.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: O, that's another matter. Well, for your perswasion, I'll do it: but if ever I speak fair to him—

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I know his nature's such, that kindness will sooner win him—Look you, he's here i'faith, as melancholy as an owl i' the day-time.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: O, are you there, Jacksauce—

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Nay, remember what I told you.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed How now, son Dick? you're melancholy still, I see.

sp.speaker: Tru. f.
sp.p: It best becomes my fortune, Sir, now you have cast me off.

sp.speaker: Tru p.
sp.p: I cast thee off? marry God forbid, Dick. How dost do, Dick? Thou lookst ill, Dick, in troth thou dost: I must have thee merry.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I see all kindness is against this dotards nature, he does so over-act it.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: Wilt thou have a Physitian, Dick? Thou art my onely son, Dick, and I must have a care of thee: thou shouldst ride abroad sometimes, Dick, and be merry. We'll ha' a wife too for thee, Dick, a good wife, ha—

sp.speaker: Tru. fil.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir; but I know not—

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: I, now he's at his know-nots. I will make you leave those know-nots, boy—

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Remember, M. Truman, what I told you.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed. Your father's old now, Dick, you see, and would fain see a grandchilde: tis out of love to you, Dick, that I perswade you to't; you may be a comfort, Dick, to your father now.

sp.speaker: Tru. f.
sp.p: You may comm • nd me.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: Well said, Dick, I see thou lovest me now, Dick; dost thou want any money, Dick? or cloathes? or horses? You sh • uld tell me what you want, you shall have any thing —here's the Captain, a hearty friend of yours—where's your Daughter, Captain? there's a wench, Dick! ha you seen her?

sp.speaker: Tru. f.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: And how do you like her, Dick? speak freely.

sp.speaker: T • u. f.
sp.p: I know no cause why any should dislike her.

sp.speaker: Tru p.
sp.p: Why well said, Dick; keep thee o' that minde still, and God will bless thee.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Your father means, Mr. Truman, I suppose, how you like her for a wife.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: I can tell my own meaning my self I hope, I'm old enough I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Tru. f.
sp.l: You wrong her much, I never shall deserve her.
Alas, I am a man so weak in all things,
So lost both to the world and to my self;
That if I lov'd a woman heartily,
And woo'd her with all zealous passions,
And valu'd her love 'bove all things else but Heaven;
Yet, when I thought upon my own unworthiness,
I should my self perswade her not to marry me.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if you esteem her worth your choise, she shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: Why what should ayre him, Captain? He esteem her? Must he, forsooth, or I be Master pray? Captain Blade, you make him too saucy with such talk; never tell me, Captain Blade, I say it makes him too saucy, I marry does it, it does i'faith; must he be his own Carver? Come no more words, I • ll have you married presently: i'saith law, Captain, you make him too saucy, that you do, you do i'faith, Sir; I can't abide when sons must come to esteem, he esteem her with a vengeance?

sp.speaker: Tru. f.
sp.p: I desire time onely to consider—

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: I, why I told you this; 'tis such a another wilful, hair-braind Coxcomb, he's always a considering. Captain Blade, I could never keep him from his considering; but I shall so consider you—go get you in, Sir, I'll have it done when I please; get you in, Sir, I'll keep you from considering hereafter. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What did you say your name was?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Jane, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well said, Iane; and as I told you, Iane, you shall have six pound a yeer, Iane, for your wages; and then my cloathes will serve you with a little alteration: There's a gown of my Cosens within will almost fit you, you're much about her height, you shall ha' that too. I had a Cousin here was a foolish thing god wot, 'tis well I'm rid of her—and d'ye hear—you must be very secret and faithful to your Mistris; a waiting womans place, is a place require, secrecy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I shall ill deserve your favour else.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay, I dare trust thee, Iane, thou lookst ingenuously: didst thou ever live at Court?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No forsooth.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O, you must learn the fashions of the Court: I'm already contracted to one Mr. Puny, though he little things of it; Take heed of speaking, Iane, you see I trust you. And when I'm married to him I'll live at Court: He's a simple thing God knows, but I'll have him knighted, and I like him the better for't: A wise woman you know will make the best use of a foolish husband. You know how to dress me, Iane, i'the Court fashion?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And you can lay me on a Fucus hansomly?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I hope I shall quickly learn it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And when you see a friend with me, or so, that I would be private with; you can stay i'the next room, and see that no body come in, to interrupt us?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I shall not be deficient in my duty.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well said. And can you tell in private such a Gentleman that you heard me speak in commendation of him, and that I dreamt of him last night? that will be in your way, Iane, such men will be grateful. And say that I was longing t'other day, for such a jewel or such a toy?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I hope you shall not finde me wanting in any service to you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I beleeve thee, Iane. To morrow I'll teach thee more: I shall read to you every day a lesson, til I see you perfect in the science: 'tis requisite that you have a little of the Theory first. Go look out the pearle chain in the Cabinet within; and stay till I come to you. Exit Iane.
The wench I see is docile, and will learn; but alas she must have time; she has a little to much City breeding, I see, by Court'sies and forsooths.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: How now? all alone, Aurelia? you're eating soap and ashes here, I warrant you, without so much as saying grace for 'um.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I'd rather repent in ashes, Sir, then eat 'um

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: What would you think if I should marry now this very day?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I should think, Sir, you'd repent to morrow for • t.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: And the widow too.

sp.speaker: Aur
sp.p: The widow? then you'll repent to night, Sir, I believe.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I woo'd her long ago, and now she sees there's an estate faln to me, faith she's content; and, to save charges, is willing to be married to day privately.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But I hope you are not so, Sir: why we shall have all the silenc'd Ministers humming and hawing thrice a week here; not a dish o' meat but will be longer a blessing then a rosting. I shall never hear my Virginals when I play upon 'um, for her daughter Tabytha's singing of Psalms. The first pious deed will be, to banish Shakespear and Ben. Iohnson out of the parlour, and to bring in their rooms Mar-prelate, and Pryns works. You'll ne'er endure 't, Sir You were wont to have a Sermon once a quarter at a good time; you shall have ten a day now.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Let me alone to deal with 'um. If any of her eating talking tribe shew their ears here, I will so use her tribe, that they shall free the Pope, and call me Antichrist hereafter: and the widow, I • ll warrant you, I'll convert: I'll carry her to Plays, in stead of Lectures: she shall see them, as well as the dancing o' the ropes, and the Puppet-play of Nineve. But this is not my business, girl: I have an husband too for you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I could wish you would keep him, Sir, if you have him; I know not what to do with him my self.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Come, 'tis a man you'll like, I'm sure; I have heard you often commend him for his parts. 'Tis young M. Truman.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Truman, Sir? the melancholy cross-arm'd Gentleman that talks to trees and rivers as he goes by 'um? We should sit all day together like pictures of man and wife, with our faces towards one another, and never speak I'll undertake, upon our Marriage-night he'll onely sigh a little, cry Cruel Fate, and then go sleep.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Never fear't. Come, thou shalt have him, girl: go quickly and dress your self; we'll both be married on a day. The humor is good, and it saves charges: there's the widows humour too.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You'll give me leave, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: No, no, no; prithee go dress thy self: by heaven it must be as I say: the fates have ordain'd it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I would not hear thee, though thou wert an Angel. I'm as resolute as he that writ the Resolves. Come away, and adorn thy self. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Me thinks. I look now like a two-peny apple pye, I know no • how.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Iohn, What's your name, Iohn? I have forgot your name, Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Do you mean the name that was given me at the Font?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Font? Font? I do not remember that Font. Let me see my scroll. (Reads.) There's ne'er a such town in Africa as Font. I do not remember Font.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Your memory, Sir, 's as short as an Ephemerides.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Did not I warn you, Iohn, of such strange what-d'ye-call ums? Here's for that word. (Strikes.) I have forgot what word 'twas: for the word I mean.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Pox take you, Dogrel, you strike too hard.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p:
Thou'dst act well, I see: we'll ha' thee to Golden-lane, and there thou shalt do
a King, or else some God in thine own cloathes.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: When a dead man from Orcus I retract,
Well may you see that to the life I act.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p:
Did not I warn you o' these what-d'ye-call-ums? 'Faith we'll be even, Master.
St • ikes him.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Very well, Iohn; those be good Memorandums for your Master.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I should be angry with thee for it, but that I ha' quite forgot it.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Let's see your scroll. (Reads) Me • morandum for my house: I have a house in Fleetstreet, with a garden to't. My daughter is call'd Lucia; a handsome fair maid with red cheeks, black eyes, and brown hair, and a little dimple in her chin. My brother's name (to whom I left the charge of my daughter) is Blade. (A most excellent Note indeed.) What ha' we here? Memorandums concerning my estate. What, they're all of this stamp, are they not? Take heed, Dogrel, the Captain's a shrewd fellow; he'll examine you more strictly then the Spanish Inquisition can.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Pish, if he pose me in any thing, my memory's weak, he knows; I h' forgot it quite.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And then your voice I fear; and then—

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Pox take you, Cutter; a Casuist would not finde so many scruples.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: The devil's in't, I shall never do this part; I know not how to speak and not be witty.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Well, look to't, gallants; if the Captain finde you out, he'll abuse you most unmercifully—I'm now for Tabytha.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: The Captain abuse me? By this day, I'll jeer with him with my hands bound behinde me. Come away, Master.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I, Iohn; but which way did we come?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Why this way, Master.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Then that way we must go. Is not this my house in Fleet street, Iohn I thought you had said t' had been in Fleet street.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Yes, so 'tis, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Truly I thought you said so. Come away, Iohn. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And the vision told me, sister Tabytha, that this same day, the twelfth of March, in the yeer of grace 1641, at this same holy place, by a holy man, we two, who are both holy vessels, should be joyned together in the holy band of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: My mother will be angry, I'm affeard.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Your mother will rejoyce. I would not for a world that you should do it, but that we were commanded from above; yea, I may say commanded: for, to do things without a divine warrant, is like unto the building of a fire without a bottom cake.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I (God knows) that it is.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Very well, sister. Now when my eyes were opened in the morning, I awoke: for it was morning-tide, and my eyes were opened; and I looked into my pockets; for my breeches lay upon a joyn'd stool not far from the beds side: and in my pockets, even made with leather, I looked (I say) and found; What did I finde? marry a License written with ink and pen: Where did I finde it? in no other place, but even in a godly Catechism which I had wrapt and folded up long-ways, even in that very pocket.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I wou'd my mother knew it. But I'll not resist, God willing.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: There is a godly Teacher within, that never was defiled with the Cap and Surplice, never wore that gambol call'd the Hood; even he shall joyn our hands. Shall we enter, sister?

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Brother, I'll not resist.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: And must we marry then?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: It appears so by the story.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Why will you marry me? What is there in me
That may deserve your liking? I shall be
The most ill-favour'd malancholy Bride-groom
That ever took a melting maid t'his bed:
The faculties of my Soul are all untun'd,
And every glory of my spreading youth
Is turn'd into a strange and sudden winter.
You cannot love me sure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No by my troth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: No, nor I you. Why should we marry then?
'Twere a meere folly, were it not Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nay, ask our Parents why. But, Sir, they say
'Tis the best marriage where like is joyned to like;
Now we two are a very even match;
For neither I love, you nor you love me;
And 'tis ten to one but we shall beget
Children that will love neither of us.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Nay, by my Soul I love you, but alas,
Not in that way that husbands love their wives;
I cannot play, nor toy, nor kiss, nor do
I know not what: And yet I was a lover,
As true a lover—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: A lack a day, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: 'Twas then me-thought the greatest happiness
To sit and talk, and look upon my Mistris,
Or (if she was not by) to think upon her.
Then every morning next to my devotion,
And sometimes too (forgive me Heav'n) before it,
She slipt into my fancy, and I took it
As a good omen for the following day.
It was a pretty foolish kind of life,
An honest harmless vanity: But now
The fairest face moves me no more then Snow
Or Lillies when I see 'um and pass by.
And I as soon shall deeply fall in love
With the fresh scarlet of an Easterne cloud,
As the red lips and cheek • of any woman.
I do confess, Aurelia, thou art fair
And very lovely, and (I think) good natur'd.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I would not willingly be a man, if they be all like you.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: And prithee now, Aurelia, tell me truly,
Are any women constant in their vowes?
Can they continue a whole week? a month?
And never change their faith? O if they could,
They would be excellent things. Nay, ne'er dissemble:
Are not their lusts unruly, insolent,
And as commanding as their beauties are?
Are their tears true and solid when they weep?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sure, Mr. Truman, you ha'n't slept of late;
If we be married to night, what will
You do for sleep?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Why? Do not married people use to sleep?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes, yes. Alas good innocence!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: They have a scurvy time of't if they do not;
But we'll not be as other people are,
We'll finde out some new hansome way of love,
Some kind of way that few shall imitate,
But all admire. For 'tis a sordid thing
That lust should dare t'insinuate it self
Into the marriage-bed. We'll get no children,
The worst of men and women can do that.
Besides too, if our issue should be female,
They would all learn to flatter and dissemble,
They'd all deceive with promises and vowes
Some simple man, and then turn false and kill him.
Would they not do't Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Our sex is little beholding to you, Sir; I would your mother were alive to hear you. But pray, Mr. Truman, what shall we do when we are married?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Why we'll live lovingly together:
Sometimes we'll sit and talk of excellent things,
And laugh at all the nonsence of the world:
Somtimes we'll walk together into the fields:
Sometimes we'll pray and read, and sometimes eat,
And sometimes sleep; and then at last we • ll die,
And go to heav'n together. 'Twill be dainty▪

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We may do this, me thinks, and never marry for the business.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: 'Tis true, we might do so:
But since our parents are resolv'd upon't,
In such a trifle let 'um have their humour.
My father sent me here to complement,
And keep a prating here, and play the fool:
I cann • t do 't. What should I do, Aurelia?
What do they use to say?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sure. Sir, you knew, when you were a suitor to my cousin Lucia.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: I, but those days are past, and I have now
Forgot what manner of man a lover is:
I was one then, I'm sure on't. O that Lucia,
That Lucia was so wonderful a creature—
There was a cheek, a lip, a nose, an eye!
Did you observe her eye, Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes, yes, Sir, you were wont to sit all day,
And look upon the pretty babies in it.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: It was as glorious as the eye of heav'n,
Like the souls eye, dispers'd through ev'ry thing.
And then her hands! her hands of liquid Ivory!
Did she but touch her Lute (the pleasing'st harmony
Then upon earth, when she her self was silent)
The subtil motion of her flying fingers
Taught Musick a new art, To take the sight
As well as th'ear.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I, I, Sir, y'had best go look her out, and marry her.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Nay prithee be not angry, good Aurelia;
I do not say she is more fair then thou art:
Yet if I did—No, but I will not say so:
Onely I strive to cherish the remembrance
Of one I lov'd so well. And, now I think on't,
I'll beg a favour of you: you'll laugh at me,
I know, when you have heard me: but I'll beg it:
Prithee be veil'd as Lucia was of late;
Cast such a silken cloud upon thy beauty
For this one day: I'd fain marry you so.
'Tis an odde foolish humour, I confess:
But love and grief may be allow'd sometimes
A little innocent folly.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well, I'll obey your humour; pray walk in there;
I'll onely dress my self, and wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: And we'll be married very privately.
None but our selves, it will be best, Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why here's a husband for a wench of clouts! May I never laugh again, if his company has not made me duller then Ale and butter'd cakes wou'd ha' done. I marry him? the old men must excuse me. I'll sooner chuse a fellow that lies bed-rid, and can do nothing a-nights but cough. Well, if I don't teach 'um what 'tis to force a wench that has wit, may my husband beat me when I have one, and I sit still and cry. I like this very well—It shall be so. Iane, come hither, Iane.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O Iane, that's well; little think you what good's towards you; 'tis that you have wisht for, I dare say, th • se five yeers; a good handsome husband. What think you of young Truman?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I think every thing
That makes a man compleat, and his wife happie,
The richest glories of a minde and body,
And their not ill companion, Fortune too,
Are reconcil'd and married all in him:
And I commend the wisdom of your stars,
That joyn you two together.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Nay saith thou shalt e'en have him
thy self for better or worse. He's too hansome indeed, unless he could make better use of his beauty; for by my troth, wench, I'm afraid thou'lt finde thy pillow as good a bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I pray do not mock your servant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Thou shalt see, Iane, I do not; come in, wench, and I'll tell thee all my plot. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Well, Sir, is the Cook doing according to my directions?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he's very hard at his business i'the kitchin: h' has been a swearing and cursing at the scullions at least this hour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: 'Tis such an over-wasted Coxcomb; an other wedding dinner would make him a S. Lau • ence: bid him be sure the Venison be well season'd

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Troth, Sir, I dare not speak to him now, unless I put on the armor in the hall: he had like to have spitted me next to a goose, for saying that he look'd like an ox that was roasted whole at S. Iame's fayre.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: You have invited a • l the guests to dinner you talk • d of?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: And the widdows round-headed kindred?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: They'l come i'their garded petticoats, will they not? You should have bid 'um eat no por • ige at home, to seem more mannerly here at dinner. The widdow will be angry at their charges, but I'll please her at night. Go bid the Butler look to his plate, and not be drunk till he sees it all in again. Whose at the door there?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, you know as well as I; some charitable beast come to be drest here. Shall I call the Cook, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Why this is my house here, Iohn: ha! ha! little thought I to have seen my house in Fleet-street again. Where's my brother Blade?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: They call me Captain Blade.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Is this he Iohn? Let me see (reads) A proper burly man, with a whitei • h beard, a quick eye, and a nose inclining to red, 'tis true Save you good brother, you did not expect me here; did you brother? Stay let me see how many yeers ago is't since we went from home?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: 'Tis now just seven, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Seven! me think's I was here but yesterday: How the what-d'ye-call-'um runs? What do ye call it?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I, I, Time. What was't I was saying? O, I was telling you brother, that I had quite forgot you: was I not telling him so Iohn?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: By my troth, Sir, we are both quits then; for I have forgot you too. Why, you were dead five yeers ago.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Was I so? I ha' quite forgot it. Iohn, was I dead five yeers ago? My memo • ry failes me very much of late▪

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: We were worse then dead I'm sure; we were taken by a barbarous kind of Nation, and there made slaves these five yeers. Iohn quoth he! I was poor Iohn indeed: I'm sure they fed us three whole yeers with nothing but Acorns and water: we lookt like wicker-bottles.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: How, Sirrah? Did your Master look like a wicked boat-man? (strikes him) Nay I remember what you said we lookt like Did we look like what-d'ye-call-ums?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Where did they take you prisoners?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Nay ask Iohn, he can tell you I warrant you. 'Twas in—tell him, Iohn, where it was.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: In Guiny, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: By what Country-men were you taken?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Why they were call'd—I know not
what they call'd 'um 'twas an odde kinde of name; but Iohn can tell you.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: 'Slife, who I Sir? d'ye think I can remember all things?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: 'Tis in my book here; I remember well the name of any Country under the Sun.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I know their names, Sir, well enough; but I onely tri'd my Masters memory. They 're call'd Tartarians.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: How say you? what were they?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Tartarians, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I, I, these were the men

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: How, Iohn! why all the world, man, lies between 'um: they live up i' the North.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: The North?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I, the very North, Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: That's true indeed: but these were another nation of the Tartarians that liv'd by us.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Well, how escap'd you, Iohn, at last?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Why 'faith, Sir, to tell you the truth, for I love not to tell a lye, the Kings daughter fell in love with me, and for my sake there set us free. My master has it all in his book; 'tis a fine story.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Strange! In what ship did you come back?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: What ship? why 'twas call'd—a thing that swims—How d'ye call it?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: What? the Mermaid?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: No, no, no, let me see—

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: What? was't the Triton?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: No, no—it swims, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: The Dolphin?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: No, no— I have forgot what 'twas.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: What say you, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: (Pox take him.) I, Sir? O God, my Master, Sir, can tell as well as I.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: He says he has forgot.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Tis his pleasure to say so, Sir: he may say what he pleases. (A plague upon him.) You can't conceive the misery we have past, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Well, brother, I'll make bold to ask one question more of you. Where did you leave your Will when you went away?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: 'Slife, now he's pos'd again.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I'll tell you presently, brother; let me see. (Reads.) Memorandum for my Will: Left to my brother Blade the whole charge of my estate—hum—What did you ask me brother?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: In what place you left your Will?

sp.speaker: Dog▪
sp.p: I, that was it indeed; you're i' the right; 'twas the very thing you askt me; and yet see how quickly I forgot it. My memory's short, alas, God help me.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: This is no answer to my question, yet.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed. What was your question, pray?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Where you left your Will.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Good lord • I had forgot you askt me this; I had forgot, i'faithlaw, that I had: you'll pardon my infirmity, I hope, brother; for alas—alas—I ha' forgot what I was going to say to you; but I was a saying somthing, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Did not you know us, Will? prithee tell's true.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, by this light: why, you're grown as black as the chimney-stock.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: That's the nature of the Country where we liv'd. O the stories that I shall tell you! And how does Nell, and little bonny Bess? are they as merry grigs as e'er they were?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No; Bess, poor wench, is married to a Chandler; but she's true blue still, as right as my leg, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: What is't, Iohn? what was I going to say, Iohn, to my brother?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I know not, Sir; was't not about your daughter?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I, I, my daughter—What d'ye call her?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Lucia, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed; my daughter Lucia, brother.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Pray walk into the parlour; I'll come to you presently, and tell you all.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Well, Iohn, put me in minde o' my daughter Lucia. (A plague o' your Tartarians.)

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: (And o' your what-d'ye-call ums.)

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: ('Slife, Tartarians.) Exeunt Dog. Pun.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
If these be rogues, they are as impudent as Mountebanks and Juglers: and if I
finde 'um to be rogues, (as I see nothing yet to the contrary) how I will exercise my rogues! The tyranny of a new Beadle over a beggar, shall be nothing to mine. Come hither, Will, what think you of these two fellows?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: 'Faith, Sir, I know not: but if you think it be not my old Master, I'll beat 'um worse then the Tartarians did.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: No, no, let's try um first. Thou wast wont to be a very precious knave, and a great acter too, a very Roscius. Didst not thou once act the Clown in Musidorus?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, Sir; but I plaid the Bear there.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: The Bear? why that's a good part; th'art an acter then, I'll warrant thee. The Bear's a well pen'd part. And you remember my brothers humour, don't you? They have almost hit it.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I know the shortness of my Masters memory; he would forget sometimes to pay me my wages till he was put in minde on't.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Well said. I'll dress thee within in his own chamber; and all the servants shall acknowledge you. But who shall do trusty Iohn?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: O, Ralph the Butler, Sir; he's an old actor, Sir, h'has plaid a King he says. I have heard him speak a Play ex tempore in the Buttry, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: O Ralph, excellent Ralph, incomparable Ralph, Ralph against the world! Come away, William; I'll give you instructions within. It must be done in the twinkling of an eye. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 6.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Now, Mistress Tabytha Cutter, let me kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Pray God my mother be not angry.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Think not o' thy mother, Spouse; I tell thee, Spouse, thou shalt be a mother thy self, within these nine months.

lg.l: Come to my bed, my dear; my dear come to my bed:
For the pleasant pain,
And the loss with gain,
Is the loss of a maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Is that a Psalm, brother husband, that you sing?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: No, no, a short ejaculatory. Sirrah boy, are the things within that I spoke for?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Go fetch 'um in. Exit Boy. Come, Tabytha, let's be merry: Canst thou sing a catch, wench? O well said, Boy!

div.stage: Enter boy with a hat and a feather, a broad band, a sword & a belt, & a periwig.

sp.speaker: Tab
sp.l: What do you mean, brother husband?
I hope you'll not turn roarer.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: What? do these cloathes befit Queen Tabytha ▪s husband? this hat with a chimny-crown, and brims no broader then a moderate hat-band? Give me the Periwig, boy. What? shall Empress Tabytha's husband go as if his head were scalded? or with the seam of a shirt for a band? Shall I walk without a sword, and not dare to quarrel i' the streets, and thrust men from the wall? Will the Fidlers be here presently, boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Pish, I can't abide these doings. Are you mad? O lord! what will my mother say? There shall come no Fidlers here.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Be peaceable, gentle Tabytha; they will not bring the Organs with 'um. I say be peaceable; he vision bid me do thus. Wilt thou resist the vision?

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: An' these be your visions—Little did I think 'twere—Is this your religion and praying? Which of all the Prophets wore such a map about his head, or such a sheet about his neck? What shall I do? I am undone.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: What shalt thou do? Why, thou shalt dance, and sing, and drink, and laugh; thou shalt go with thy brests open, and thy hair braided; thou shalt put fine black stars upon thy face, and have great bobs for thy ears. Nay, if thou dost begin to look rustily, I'll have thee paint thy face like the whore of B • bylon.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: O that ever I was born to see this day!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: What? dost thou weep, Queen Did • ? Thou shalt have Sack to drive away thy sorrow. Come hither, boy, fetch me a quart of Canary. (Exit boy.) Thou shalt see I'll be a loving husband to thee. The vision, Tabytha, bid me give you drink: we must obey these visions. Sing, Tabytha: Cry on your wedding-day? 'tis ominous.

lg.l: Come to my bed, my dear;
Come to my bed:
For the pleasant pain— Enter boy with wine.

sp.p: O art thou come, boy— Well said, fill a brimmer; nay fuller yet, yet a little fuller. So. Here's to the Lady-Spouse; to our good sport to night.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Drink it your self, if you will; I'll not touch it.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: By this hand, thou shalt pledge me, seeing the vision said so. Drink, or I'll take a Coach and carry thee to a Play immediately.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I can't abide— (She drinks.)

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why, this will clear thy heart, wench: Sack, and an husband, wench, are both comfortable things. Have at you again.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I'll pledge you no more. not I.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Here, take this glass, and take it off too, or else I'll swear an hundred oathes in a breathing-time. Here—

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Well, you're the strangest man—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why this is right now. Nay off with it. So. But the vision said that whatsoever we left of this same wine, would turn to poison straight. There, here's to you, Tabytha, once again: 'tis the visions will.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: What? must I drink again, then? Well, I'll not resist. You're such another brother-husband. (Drinks.) There's a whole one now—

lg.l: Come to my bed, my dear;
Come to my bed—

sp.p: How was't? Twas a pretty one.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: O divine Tabytha! Here come the Fidlers too. Strike up, you rogues.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: What? must we dance now? is not that the fashion? I could have danc'd the Coranto when I was a girl. The Coranto's a curious dance.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: We'll dance out the disease of the Tarantula: but first we'll have a health to my pretty Tabytha.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I'll begin't my self. Here, Duck, here's to all that love us.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: A health, you eternal scrapers sound a health. Bravely done, Tabytha: what thinkst thou now o' thy mother?

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: A fig for my mother; I'll be a mother my self. Come, Duckling, shall we go home?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Go home? the Bride and the Bridegroom go? We'll dance home. Afore us, squeakers: that way, and be hang'd. So. O brave Queen Tabytha! excellent Empress Tabytha! On, you rogues They go out dancing, with the musick before 'um.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I must not be fob'd off thus about my daughter: I remember not your excuse; but Iohn can tell well enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I have told you the plain truth: you'll not be angry, I hope.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I shall have cause to be angry, I fear: Did not I leave her to his charge, Iohn? Brother, I tell you—

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I must not answer, brother—

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I know you put me out, that I might forget what I said to you before: remember, Iohn: I'll be as cunning as you're crafty: remember, John. How now? what's the matter? Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Ho, my old Master's come; he's lighted now at the door with his man John: he's asking for you; he longs to see you: my Master, my old Master.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: This fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: If you wo'n't believe me, go in and see, Sir: he's not so much alter'd, but you'll quickly know him. I knew him as soon as I saw him. Pray, Sir, go in. Exeunt Blade and servant.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Why this is strange.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: If this be true, what course shall we take, Dogrel? I begin to shake like a plum-tree-leaf.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: We'll shift some way or other, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: How, Dogrel? prithee how?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Let the worst come, we can be but whipt, or burnt in the hand, a • the most.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Ho, our best way will be to hang our selves—'Slife, here's John.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen 8.
div.stage: Dogrel, Puny, John, two or three servants.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.p: Give me thy hand i'faith, boy: is't possible that thou shouldst be alive still?

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p: Ha rogue! art thou come i'faith? I have a pottle o' Sack to welcome thee.

sp.speaker: 3 Se • v.
sp.p: Why you'll not look upon your poor friends, John Give me thy golls, John. How hast thou done this great while?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I thank you all heartily for your love; thank you with all my heart-law. What? my old bed-fellow Robin? how dost do? when shall we steal Apricocks ag • in? d'ye remember, Robin?

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p: A murrain take you; you'll never forget your roguery.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: A murrain take you all: this was your plot, and be hang'd▪ Would I were Puny the Wit again.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Accursed Fate—

sp.speaker: 3 Serv.
sp.p: Come, John, let's go to the Buttry and be merry: Ralph longs to see you, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: And how does Ralph? good honest Ralph? That Ralp's as honest a fellow, though I say't my self; I love him with all my heart-law, that I do; and there's no love lost, I dare say for him.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p: Come, my masters, will you go in? I'll prevail with the Cook for a slice or two of Beef; and we'll have a cup of Stingo, the best in the ce • lar.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Well said, steel to the back still; that was your word, you know. My master • s coming in: go. I'll follow you straight.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.p: Make haste, good John, for I can't stay. Exeunt Servants.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Here's a company of as honest fellows a • sa ma • would with to live i' the house withal; all, no man excepted▪

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Would I were out of the house, as honest as they are. Here they come, John.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: John, quoth he, with a pox.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Me thinks you're not return'd, Sir,
But born to us anew, and I could wish
My tongue were not more niggardly then my heart
In giving you a welcom.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Thank you good brother. Truly we ha' past through many dangers; my man shall tell you all, I'm old and crasy, and forget these things. Enter Widow.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Pox on't, the Widow's come already; keep 'um here John, till I come back. O are you here sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Who have you yonder, I pray?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: O you should not ha' seen 'um yet, they are Maskers.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Not vagrant players, I hope?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: No, no, they can onely tumble, and dance upon the rope, you shall see 'um after dinner. Let • s away sweet-heart, the Parson stays for us, he has blown his fingers this hour. Exeunt Blade and the Widow.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I'm glad the Captain's gone, now will I sneak away, like one that has stolen a silver-spoone.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I'll be your man and follow you.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Who are these Iohn? By your leave, Sir; would you speak with any here?

sp.speaker: Dog
sp.p: The Captain, Sir. But I'll take some other time to wait on him, my occasions call me now.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Nay, pray, Sir, stay. Whom did you say you would speak withall?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: The Captain, Sir. But another time will serve. I ha' some haste of business.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Whom would he speak with, Iohn? I forget still.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: The Captain Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Captain? What Captain Sir?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Your brother I suppose he is.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
'Ti, true indeed, I had forgot that my brother was a Captain. I cry you mercy,
Sir, he'll be here presently. Are you an English-man, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Where were you born I pray?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: In London, Sir. I must leave you—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: In London? y'are an English-man then I see, Sir. Would you have spoke with me Sir?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: No, with your brother, but my business with him requires not haste, and therefore—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: You're not in haste you say; pray sit down then: may I crave your name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: My name's not worth your knowlede, Sir; but my mans name's Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: (If I be John any more I'll be hang'd) No my name's Timothy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Mr. John Timothy? Very well, Sir. You seem to Be a Travellor.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: We're newly come out of Affrick, and therefore have some business that requires us

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Of Affrick? Law you there now. What Country pray?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Prester John's Country. Fare you well, Sir. now.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Marry God forbid. What come from Prester John, and we not drink a cup of Sack together?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: (What shall I do?) Friend, shall I trouble you to shew me where your house of office is?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: You'll stay here Mr.—what's your name, pray?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Timothy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Gods me, 'tis true indeed Mr. John Timothy.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Ill only make water, and come to you.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: The door, Sir, is lockt; the Captain has lockt us all in here, if you • ll be pleas'd to stay, Sir, till he comes—

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: (I'd as live stay to meet the Devil, or a Sargeant.)

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: (Would I were hid like maggot in a pescod; we shall be abused I see, oh, oh, oh,)

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: What makes you quake so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Nothing, onely I have an extream list to make water: 'Tis nothing else by this light.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: My brother would not have you gone it seems. Your names Mr. John Timothy, is it?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: No, that's my mans name.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O, your mans name; 'tis true, 'tis very true indeed, that's your man's name. You'll pardon me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Pray, friend, do you know the great City call'd Astervadil, where my name-sake Prester-Iohn keeps his Court?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Know't? I, very well; I have liv'd there a great while, I have cause to know't.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Ther's a brave Castle of three miles long.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I, and many stately building too.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: The noble mens houses are all built of Marble.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: They make indeed a glorious show. I ha' seen 'um.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: It may be so. But to my knowledg, friend, there is no such City there.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: It may be the names are alter'd since I was there. (Here's the Captain, I'll sneak behind the hangings.)

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 10.
div.stage: Dogrel, Puny, William, Iohn, Blade, VVidow.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I like this Person well, h' has made short work on't, he had appointed sure some meetting at an Ale-house. Welcome wife, welcome home now. But I ha' two brethren which you must know.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marry, Heav'ns for • sheild, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Brethren in God sweet-heart, no otherwise. Come hither Guiny brother; what say you?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: This Gentleman, Brother, has stay'd for you here; pray use him kindly, he's a Traveller: where did you say you travell'd Sir?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: O yes! How do you, brother?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I your brother? what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Why, are not you my brother Blade that was taken captive by the Tartars? Ha!

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: You're merrily dispos'd, Sir: I your brother! I taken captive by the Tartars! Ha, ha, ha! I understand not your meaning, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: What an impudent slave's this! Sirrah monster, didst not thou come with thy man Iohn?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I, my man Iohn? here's no such fellow here, you see: how you're mistaken, Sir! you mean some other man. This is the strangest humour.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Sirrah, dost thou see this fist? dost thou see this foot? I'll wear these out upon thee—

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Hold, pray Sir, hold. I remember now indeed that I was Blade the Merchant; but I had quite forgot it. You must pardon me; my memory's very weak.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I like the humour. But I must know, Sir, who you are, now you ha' left being my brother.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Who, I? don't you know me? I'm Dogrel the Poet, and Puny was my man Iohn. Lord that you should not know▪ me all this while! not know Poet Dogrel!

lg.l: Why I intended here this merry play,
To solemnize your nuptial-day.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: O thank you, M. Dogrel; Can you dance upon the ropes, and tumble? Truely I never knew it before, not I.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Where's that fool, Puny? Is he slipt away?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: (He was wise enough to do so, I'll warrant you.)

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I will beat him so, that he shall not finde a similitude for himself. As for you, Dogrel, because you came off pretty handsomely, with the best at the last, like an Epigram, I may chance to pardon you; but upon this condition, that you make no Epithalamiums upon my marriage.

Well said, Will; bravely done,
He pulls off his mens d • sguises.
Will: i'faith thou shalt ha' two laces more to thy Livery, for doing this so well. I told thee, Will, what 'twas to have acted the Bear in Musidorus. And Ralph was a brave Iohn too—

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: How's this? I plainly see I'm an Ass then: 'twas this damn'd Puny's fearfulness spoil'd all.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: (A pox o' this coward Dogrel: I thought they were not the right ones.)

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I see my Players had more wit then my Poet. Here's something for you to drink. Go in now: this is your Cue of Exit; and see all things there in a readiness.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay, let the Master go first. Follow me, Iohn. Exeunt Will. and Ralph.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: What, husband? Ha' you giv'n 'um any thing? Indeed, Love, you're too lavish.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: 'Twas very wittily put off o' me, howsoever.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 11.
div.stage: Blade, Widow, Dogrel, Puny, Cutter, and Tabytha, with Fidlers before 'um.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: How now? what ha' we here? another Puppet-play? Any thing now but brothers, and I'm for 'um. Who? Cutter? What's the matter, Poet? Come, what device is this? like one o' yours?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Stay at the door, ye sempiternal squeakers. Come, Queen o' fame.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Lord, I'm so weary with dancing as passes. Yonder's my mother. Oh mother! what d'ye think I ha' been doing to day?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why what, childe?

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Nay nothing: I have onely been married a little; and my husband and I ha' so danc'd it since!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Brave Tabytha still! Never be angry, Widow; you know where Marriages are made. How now, Captain? If I turn Tapster now, 'twill be happie for you: for I shall be rich enough to trust you, Captain.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: 'Twas Gods will, I see, and therefore there's no resisting. But what d'ye mean, son? I hope you'll not turn swaggerer?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: 'Tis for special reasons, gentle mother. Why how now, Dogrel? M. Blade the Merchant looks as if he were broke: he has turn'd away his servant too.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Who's that? M. Dogrel i' these Players clothes? Can M. Dogrel dance too, husband?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Prithee, Cutter, what hath exalted Tabytha thus?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: What? this good fortune she has got by me: You know what a dull creature she was before; her soul was in her body, like butter in a hot cake; now she's as full of Spirits as Hell it self. My counsel and two cups o' Sack, have wrought this miracle.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 12.
div.stage: To these, Truman Pater, Truman Filius, Lucia veil'd.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: Well said! You are joyn'd then now, my blessing on you both; come in to your father Blade. Nay, daughter Aurelia, off with your veil now. Ha! Whom ha' you married here?

sp.speaker: Tru. f.
sp.p: I know not, Sir. She was Aurelia when we went to Church.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: This is my daughters maid. Where's the wench? Ho! Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Here, Sir? Why do you make your husband lead your maid in thus?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: My husband, Sir? what's that?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Why, huswife is not Mr. Truman your husband?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No, by my troth, Sir, I thank God.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: These are fine tricks; delicate, dainty tricks. Sirrah, how durst you Sirrah?—and for your minion—marry come up, marry a Chamber-maid? Well, Captain, this was your plotting. You said indeed you'd make a Iethron o' me: y' ha' don't indeed; I thank you, Captain Blade, 'tis well. Out o' my sight, Sir, with your minion there, I say out o' my sight. Ha! am I fool'd thus? I shall make some repent it, I hold a groate on't.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: D'ye hear, Mr. Truman—

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I do hear; and I will not hear if it please me, Sir; but some body shall hear o' this Captain. But, Captain, you're deceived, this is not a lawful marriage.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray, hear me all; for I shall tell those things
That will appease your wrath, and move your wonder.
I've married Truman, and I will enjoy him,
And he will love me, I am sure he will;
For I am Lucia, the much injure'd Lucia.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The habit of a servant I put on,
That I might finde who 'twas I ought to pardon,
For all the wrongs done to me. I have found it,
Cosen, you know I have, and I forgive 'um.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then all my plots are spoil'd. Pardon me, Cousin:
And, Mr. Truman, know you have a wife
That is as pure and innocent as the thoughts
Of dying Saints? 'Twas I that with the veile
Deceiv'd you in the Prison; it was I,
Who in that veile contracted my self to Puny.
Forgive me both; I do confess I've wrong'd you,
But Heav'n has seen you righted.

sp.speaker: Tru. f.
sp.l: O this blest hour!
What shall I say? I know thou art all goodness,
But canst thou pardon, Lucia, that great sin,
That high and mighty sin which I have done
In doubting of thy faith? I fear thou canst not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I do desire no more then that I may,
Deserve your better opinion, Sir, hereafter.
And uncle for your poyson—

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Speak no more of it,
I do confess it, Neece; and shall most willingly
Surrender up the charge of your Estate.
It hath pleas'd Heav'n to restore me mine own
By marriage with this Widow.

sp.speaker: Tru. p.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! To see how things are come about! I thought Dick would not
be such a fool as to marry one that he knew not. He knew her well enough, I'll warrant you. How do you, Captain? I was somewhat rash: I'm an old man, alas.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Cutter, and M. Dogrel, you that sneak there;
You're precious witnesses. But no more o' that.
You have been to blame, Aurelia. But 'tis past.
We want your husband here: Where's Puny?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: (I'll venture out amongst 'um.) Enter Puny. Nay ne'er laugh at me; I know I look like a door without hinges. A pox upon you, Dogrel; are you there?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: What? my son Iohn? d'ye know this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: D'ye know this piece of gold, Sir, which you broke?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Hum? Yes 'faith, 'tis the same: thou art my Cynthia, wench, my Endymion: we'll be married presently. O for a witty Parson to marry us two Wi • s!

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Slife, one, two, three, i'faith four matches here at one time! What accursed fortune • s this! there's three feasts lost: they'll dine all together.

sp.speaker: Pun
sp.p: I will not kiss thee, my little magazine, till I have washt my face Ha, M. Dogrel, hast thou got no Spouse too?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: The thrice three Sisters are my wives.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Well, because thou art a Poet, and my Jews-trump and I are Wits, thou shalt eat and drink at my pavilion always.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You shall ha' wine and serge. D'ye remember, Dogrel?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Thank you: but I'll ne'er lye for you again.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Come, let's all in to dinner.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: THe Play is done, great Prince, which needs must fear,
Though you brought all your fathers mercies here,
It may offend your Highness, and we've now
Three hours done treason here, for ought we know.
But pow'r your Grace can above Nature give;
It can give pow'r to make abortives live.
In which if our bold wishes should be crost,
'Tis but the life of one poor week that's lost.
Though it should fall beneath your present scorn,
It could not die sooner then it was born.
